content: That 'tiger by the tail' syndrome that was so much ineffect while the insurgency was active in Iraq is sneaking its way into the economy now. http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d09294sp.pdf The Government Accountability Office released a position paper for Congress heading up the expected massive costs of withdrawing troops, and their equipment from Iraq. Even a best case scenario where the cake and flowers show up for the troops going home will cost as much or more as it cost to put them there. Add to that a large amount of equipment might be might be nearing the end of its usefulness. Some might be totally inappropriate for service in other theatres. It will be a while, if at all, before there is any 'peace dividend' from Iraq .... Afghanistan too.
reply: That 'tiger by the tail' syndrome that was so much ineffect while the insurgency was active in Iraq is sneaking its way into the economy now. http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d09294sp.pdf The Government Accountability Office released a position paper for Congress heading up the expected massive costs of withdrawing troops, and their equipment from Iraq. Even a best case scenario where the cake and flowers show up for the troops going home will cost as much or more as it cost to put them there. Add to that a large amount of equipment might be might be nearing the end of its usefulness. Some might be totally inappropriate for service in other theatres. It will be a while, if at all, before there is any 'peace dividend' from Iraq .... Afghanistan too.
title: GAO: Big Bucks to Leave Iraq

content: quote: Originally posted by popsiq: That 'tiger by the tail' syndrome that was so much ineffect while the insurgency was active in Iraq is sneaking its way into the economy now. http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d09294sp.pdf The Government Accountability Office released a position paper for Congress heading up the expected massive costs of withdrawing troops, and their equipment from Iraq. Even a best case scenario where the cake and flowers show up for the troops going home will cost as much or more as it cost to put them there. Add to that a large amount of equipment might be might be nearing the end of its usefulness. Some might be totally inappropriate for service in other theatres. It will be a while, if at all, before there is any 'peace dividend' from Iraq .... Afghanistan too. The everyone knew this was the case. Hell the whole military knew it. It cost more to remove equipment than to get it there. Best thing to do to make it cheap is blow it up so that it is unuseable by the enemy. Congress lives in some magical land where they think their **** don't stink and they can do whatever they want. "A government big enough to give you everything you want, is strong enough to take everything you have." ~ Gerald Ford
